title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: approximate situation examined study, simulate FAQ, MMSE MoCA data common multivariate. words, subject ii assumed following vector latent scores: Yi=[FAQiMMSEiMoCAi]‚àº‚Ñ≥ùí±ùí©3(ùõç,ùö∫)(1)  Y_i = \begin{bmatrix} FAQ_i \\ MMSE_i \\ MoCA_i \end{bmatrix} \sim \mathcal{MVN_3}(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma})  \qquad(1) ùõç\boldsymbol\mu denotes vector means ùö∫\boldsymbol\Sigma variance‚Äìcovariance matrix. Across simulations, vector means fixed based observed data (see Table¬†1): ùõç=[4.0526.6924.07](2) \boldsymbol\mu = \begin{bmatrix} 4.05 \\ 26.69 \\ 24.07 \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(2) Two different specification variance-covariance matrix used. first, based observed data (Table¬†1), represents correlated scenario: ùö∫corr=[23.91‚àí2.28‚àí4.59‚àí2.284.934.87‚àí4.594.8724.07](3) \boldsymbol\Sigma_{corr} =   \begin{bmatrix} 23.91 & -2.28 & -4.59 \\                   -2.28 &  4.93 & 4.87  \\                   -4.59 &  4.87 & 24.07   \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(3) simulate independent scenario, covariance FAQ MMSE/MoCA set zero, yielding: ùö∫indep=[23.910004.934.8704.8724.07](4) \boldsymbol\Sigma_{indep} =   \begin{bmatrix} 23.91 &  0    & 0    \\                    0    &  4.93 & 4.87  \\                    0    &  4.87 & 24.07   \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(4) simulate data FAQ item 9, assumed ùõï\boldsymbol{\tau}-equivalence FAQ (.e., items share true score, cf. Trizano-Hermosilla Alvarado (2016)). applied probit link FAQ total score simulated patient obtain probability positive response item: pi=œï(zi)(5) p_i = \phi(z_i)  \qquad(5) œï(‚ãÖ)\phi(\cdot) standard normal cumulative distribution function ziz_i standardised FAQ score simulated patient ii. observed FAQ item 9 score subsequently drawn binomial distribution via: FAQ item 9i‚àº‚Ñ¨ùíæùìÉ‚Ñ¥ùìÇùíæùí∂ùìÅ(n=4,pi)(6) \text{FAQ item 9}_i \sim \mathcal{Binomial}(n = 4, p_i)  \qquad(6) simulated FAQ item 9 score exceeded corresponding simulated FAQ total score, set zero. Finally, simulated FAQ total, MMSE MoCA scores left-censored 0 right-censored 30 reflect real-world range respective scales.
code: # Simulation parameters: n <- 2000 # sample size high enough to get stable estimates k <- 2000 # enough iterations to see trends   # Moments of the multivariate normal distribution: mu <- c(FAQ = 4.05, MMSE = 26.69, MoCA = 24.07) # vector of means sigma <- c(FAQ = 4.89, MMSE = 2.22, MoCA = 3.48) # vector of standard deviations  # Correlation matrix from observed data: corrs <- matrix(   c(1, -0.21, -0.27,     -0.21, 1, 0.63,     -0.27, 0.63, 1),   nrow = 3,   dimnames = list(     c("FAQ", "MMSE", "MoCA"),     c("FAQ", "MMSE", "MoCA")   ) )  # Get variance-covariance matrix for the correlated case: sigma_corr <- cor2cov(corrs, sigma)  # Set FAQ/cognition covariances to zero for the independent case: sigma_indep <- sigma_corr sigma_indep["FAQ", ] <- c(sigma_indep["FAQ", "FAQ"], 0, 0) sigma_indep[, "FAQ"] <- c(sigma_indep["FAQ", "FAQ"], 0, 0) # Data-generating function: simulate_pdd <- function(N, Mu, Sigma) {   # Generate FAQ, MMSE and MoCA latent data:   dat <- as.data.frame(MASS::mvrnorm(N, mu = Mu, Sigma = Sigma))   # Generate FAQ item 9 data:   p <- pnorm(dat$FAQ, mean = Mu["FAQ"], sd = sqrt(Sigma["FAQ", "FAQ"]))   dat$FAQ9 <- rbinom(N, size = 4, prob = p)   dat$FAQ9 <- ifelse(dat$FAQ9 > dat$FAQ, 0, dat$FAQ9)   # Bound scores realistically:   dat$FAQ  <- pmin(pmax(round(dat$FAQ), 0), 30)   dat$MMSE <- pmin(pmax(round(dat$MMSE), 0), 30)   dat$MoCA <- pmin(pmax(round(dat$MoCA), 0), 30)   # Define PDD classifications:   dat$A1 <- as.numeric(dat$FAQ > 7 & dat$MMSE < 26)   dat$A2 <- as.numeric((dat$FAQ9 > 1) & dat$MMSE < 26)   dat$A3 <- as.numeric(dat$FAQ > 7 & dat$MoCA < 27)   dat$A4 <- as.numeric((dat$FAQ9 > 1) & dat$MoCA < 27)   # Return the data:   dat }

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: approximate situation examined study, simulate FAQ, MMSE MoCA data common multivariate. words, subject ii assumed following vector latent scores: Yi=[FAQiMMSEiMoCAi]‚àº‚Ñ≥ùí±ùí©3(ùõç,ùö∫)(1)  Y_i = \begin{bmatrix} FAQ_i \\ MMSE_i \\ MoCA_i \end{bmatrix} \sim \mathcal{MVN_3}(\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma})  \qquad(1) ùõç\boldsymbol\mu denotes vector means ùö∫\boldsymbol\Sigma variance‚Äìcovariance matrix. Across simulations, vector means fixed based observed data (see Table¬†1): ùõç=[4.0526.6924.07](2) \boldsymbol\mu = \begin{bmatrix} 4.05 \\ 26.69 \\ 24.07 \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(2) Two different specification variance-covariance matrix used. first, based observed data (Table¬†1), represents correlated scenario: ùö∫corr=[23.91‚àí2.28‚àí4.59‚àí2.284.934.87‚àí4.594.8724.07](3) \boldsymbol\Sigma_{corr} =   \begin{bmatrix} 23.91 & -2.28 & -4.59 \\                   -2.28 &  4.93 & 4.87  \\                   -4.59 &  4.87 & 24.07   \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(3) simulate independent scenario, covariance FAQ MMSE/MoCA set zero, yielding: ùö∫indep=[23.910004.934.8704.8724.07](4) \boldsymbol\Sigma_{indep} =   \begin{bmatrix} 23.91 &  0    & 0    \\                    0    &  4.93 & 4.87  \\                    0    &  4.87 & 24.07   \end{bmatrix}  \qquad(4)

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: simulate data FAQ item 9, assumed ùõï\boldsymbol{\tau}-equivalence FAQ (.e., items share true score, cf. Trizano-Hermosilla Alvarado (2016)). applied probit link FAQ total score simulated patient obtain probability positive response item: pi=œï(zi)(5) p_i = \phi(z_i)  \qquad(5) œï(‚ãÖ)\phi(\cdot) standard normal cumulative distribution function ziz_i standardised FAQ score simulated patient ii. observed FAQ item 9 score subsequently drawn binomial distribution via: FAQ item 9i‚àº‚Ñ¨ùíæùìÉ‚Ñ¥ùìÇùíæùí∂ùìÅ(n=4,pi)(6) \text{FAQ item 9}_i \sim \mathcal{Binomial}(n = 4, p_i)  \qquad(6) simulated FAQ item 9 score exceeded corresponding simulated FAQ total score, set zero. Finally, simulated FAQ total, MMSE MoCA scores left-censored 0 right-censored 30 reflect real-world range respective scales.
code: # Data-generating function: simulate_pdd <- function(N, Mu, Sigma) {   # Generate FAQ, MMSE and MoCA latent data:   dat <- as.data.frame(MASS::mvrnorm(N, mu = Mu, Sigma = Sigma))   # Generate FAQ item 9 data:   p <- pnorm(dat$FAQ, mean = Mu["FAQ"], sd = sqrt(Sigma["FAQ", "FAQ"]))   dat$FAQ9 <- rbinom(N, size = 4, prob = p)   dat$FAQ9 <- ifelse(dat$FAQ9 > dat$FAQ, 0, dat$FAQ9)   # Bound scores realistically:   dat$FAQ  <- pmin(pmax(round(dat$FAQ), 0), 30)   dat$MMSE <- pmin(pmax(round(dat$MMSE), 0), 30)   dat$MoCA <- pmin(pmax(round(dat$MoCA), 0), 30)   # Define PDD classifications:   dat$A1 <- as.numeric(dat$FAQ > 7 & dat$MMSE < 26)   dat$A2 <- as.numeric((dat$FAQ9 > 1) & dat$MMSE < 26)   dat$A3 <- as.numeric(dat$FAQ > 7 & dat$MoCA < 27)   dat$A4 <- as.numeric((dat$FAQ9 > 1) & dat$MoCA < 27)   # Return the data:   dat }

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: generating data using process described , simulated patient classified suffering PDD () according following four algorithms: A1i=ùüô{FAQi>7‚àßMMSEi<26},A2i=ùüô{FAQ item 9i>1‚àßMMSEi<26},A3i=ùüô{FAQi>7‚àßMoCAi<27},A4i=ùüô{FAQ item 9i>1‚àßMoCAi<27}(7) \begin{aligned}   A1_i &= \mathbb{1}\{\text{FAQ}_i > 7 \ \wedge\ \text{MMSE}_i < 26\}, \\   A2_i &= \mathbb{1}\{\text{FAQ item 9}_i > 1 \ \wedge\ \text{MMSE}_i < 26\}, \\   A3_i &= \mathbb{1}\{\text{FAQ}_i > 7 \ \wedge\ \text{MoCA}_i < 27\}, \\   A4_i &= \mathbb{1}\{\text{FAQ item 9}_i > 1 \ \wedge\ \text{MoCA}_i < 27\} \end{aligned}  \qquad(7) ùüô{‚ãÖ}\mathbb{1}\{\cdot\} denotes indicator function. words, simulated cases fulfilling conditions parentheses classified PDD (PDD = 1); others classified non-PDD (PDD = 0). ensure reliable results, N = 2000 cases generated experiment. simulation based observed means, standard deviations correlations specified . independent variable experiment presence versus absence correlation FAQ cognitive scores. Accordingly, simulation conducted two conditions: Independent scenario using ùö∫indep\boldsymbol\Sigma_{indep} (Equation¬†4), Correlated scenario using ùö∫corr\boldsymbol\Sigma_{corr} (Equation¬†3). simulation parameters (.e., number participants, vector variable means, variances variables, covariance MMSE MoCA) held constant across conditions.
code: d0 <- simulate_pdd(n, mu, sigma_indep) # independent scenario d1 <- simulate_pdd(n, mu, sigma_corr)  # correlated scenario

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: ensure reliable results, N = 2000 cases generated experiment. simulation based observed means, standard deviations correlations specified . independent variable experiment presence versus absence correlation FAQ cognitive scores. Accordingly, simulation conducted two conditions: Independent scenario using ùö∫indep\boldsymbol\Sigma_{indep} (Equation¬†4), Correlated scenario using ùö∫corr\boldsymbol\Sigma_{corr} (Equation¬†3). simulation parameters (.e., number participants, vector variable means, variances variables, covariance MMSE MoCA) held constant across conditions.
code: d0 <- simulate_pdd(n, mu, sigma_indep) # independent scenario d1 <- simulate_pdd(n, mu, sigma_corr)  # correlated scenario

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: generated data, following statistical estimates computed within scenario (.e., independent correlated): PDD rate algorithm, accuracy pair algorithms, balanced accuracy pair algorithms, Cohen‚Äôs ùõã\boldsymbol\kappa pair algorithms. procedure repeated 2000 iterations. Subsequently, distributions PDD rates concordance measures compared (pairs ) algorithms across two scenarios. Independent samples t-tests used compute 95% confidence intervals differences scenarios within diagnostic algorithm.
code: # Function for comparing two algorithms within the same scenario: compare_algos <- function(dat, a1, a2) {   x <- dat[[a1]]   y <- dat[[a2]]   cm <- caret::confusionMatrix(factor(x), factor(y), positive = "1")   k <- psych::cohen.kappa(cbind(x, y))$kappa   data.frame(     Accuracy = cm$overall["Accuracy"],     BalAcc = cm$byClass["Balanced Accuracy"],     Kappa = k   ) }  # Function for results summary: summarise_results <- function(d0, d1, r = 1) {   # PDD rates:   rates <- map_dfr(paste0("A", 1:4), function(i) {     c(indep = mean(d0[[i]]),       corrs = mean(d1[[i]])       )   }) |>     mutate(diff = corrs - indep, rep  = r) |>     rownames_to_column("algo")   # Concordance:   conc <- expand.grid(     ref = paste0("A", 1:4),     pred = paste0("A", 1:4),     scenario = c("indep", "corrs")   )   for (i in c("Accuracy", "BalAcc", "Kappa")) {     conc[[i]] <- NA   }   for (i in seq_len(nrow(conc))) {     y <- as.character(conc[i, "ref"])     x <- as.character(conc[i, "pred"])     if (conc[i, "scenario"] == "indep") {       conc[i , c("Accuracy", "BalAcc", "Kappa")] <- compare_algos(d0, x, y)     } else if (conc[i, "scenario"] == "corrs") {       conc[i, c("Accuracy", "BalAcc", "Kappa")] <- compare_algos(d1, x, y)     }   }   conc$rep <- r   # Return the results:   list(rates = rates, concordance = as_tibble(conc)) }

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: expected values (denoted E(‚ãÖ)E(\cdot)) differences independent correlated scenarios PDD rates, accuracy, balanced accuracy Cohen‚Äôs Œ∫\kappa presented Table¬†2, Table¬†3, Table¬†4, Table¬†5, respectively. Across algorithms, correlated scenario generated higher PDD rates independent scenario, differences approximately 2‚Äì3% (Table¬†2). Table¬†2: Expectations PDD rates differences independent correlated scenarios based independent sample t-tests. effect data-generating scenario concordance indeces nuanced. accuracy, correlated scenario generally yielded slightly lower estimates independent one across algorithm pairs (Table¬†3). However, magnitude differences exceed 1%. Table¬†3: Expectations accuracy estimates differences independent correlated scenarios based independent sample t-tests. Results balanced accuracy heterogeneous (Table¬†4). algorithm pairs IADL global cognition criteria mismatched (e.g., A1 vs A4), balanced accuracy consistently higher correlated scenario, roughly 3%. mismatch concerned IADL criterion, direction difference balanced accuracy reversed depending algorithm used reference (e.g., A1 predicted A2, correlated scenario yielded lower balanced accuracy, whereas A2 predicted A1, yielded higher values). magnitude effect comparable directions. Finally, mismatch involved global cognition criterion, correlated scenario led higher balanced accuracy estimates three four cases. maximum difference similar comparison types, reaching 3.8%. Table¬†4: Expectations balanced accuracy estimates differences independent correlated scenarios based independent sample t-tests. Lastly, Cohen‚Äôs Œ∫\kappa showed clearest consistent pattern results (Table¬†5). cases, correlated scenario yielded higher Œ∫\kappa values independent one, differences ranging 0.010 0.070. Table¬†5: Expectations Cohen‚Äôs Œ∫ estimates differences independent correlated scenarios based independent sample t-tests.
code: # Calculate all results: res <- lapply(seq_len(k), function(i) {   d0 <- simulate_pdd(n, mu, sigma_indep)   d1 <- simulate_pdd(n, mu, sigma_corr)   summarise_results(d0, d1, i) })  # Extract PDD rates and concordance separately: res_rates <- map_dfr(seq_len(k), \(i) res[[i]]$rates) res_conc <- map_dfr(seq_len(k), \(i) res[[i]]$conc)  # Conduct t-tests for PDD rates: stats_rates <- res_rates |>   pivot_longer(c(indep, corrs), names_to = "scenario", values_to = "rate") |>   group_by(algo) |>   rstatix::t_test(rate ~ scenario, detailed = TRUE, var.equal = TRUE) |>   mutate(     Algorithm = glue::glue("A{algo}"),     Independent = estimate2,     Correlated = estimate1,     Difference = estimate,     Low = conf.low,     High = conf.high   ) |>   dplyr::select(Algorithm, Independent, Correlated, Difference, Low, High)  # Conduct t-tests for concordance metrics: stats_conc <- map_dfr(c("Accuracy", "BalAcc", "Kappa"), function(y) {   res_conc |>     filter(ref != pred) |>     mutate(Comparison = glue::glue("{ref}{pred}")) |>     group_by(Comparison) |>     rstatix::t_test(formula(glue::glue("{y} ~ scenario")), detailed = TRUE, var.equal = TRUE) |>     mutate(       Index = y,       Independent = estimate1,       Correlated = estimate2,       Difference = estimate,       Low = conf.low,       High = conf.high,       Type = case_when(         Comparison %in% c("A1A3", "A3A1", "A2A4", "A4A2") ~ "Aligned IADL & Mismatched Global Cognition",         Comparison %in% c("A1A2", "A2A1", "A3A4", "A4A3") ~ "Mismatched IADL & Aligned Global Cognition",         Comparison %in% c("A1A4", "A4A1", "A2A3", "A3A2") ~ "Mismatched IADL & Mismatched Global Cognition"       )     ) |>     dplyr::select(Index, Type, Comparison, Independent, Correlated, Difference, Low, High) })

title: Impact of Correlation on Concordance
text: Tip Based simulations presented vignette, can conclude correlations FAQ global cognition measures magnitude observed empirical data imply : correlated scenario sensitive PDD, consistently yielding higher PDD rates, correlated scenario produces accuracy estimates similar independent scenario, considering balanced accuracy, correlated scenario diverges independent one nuanced ways, yielding higher estimates comparisons lower others, relative independent scenario, correlated scenario tends slightly overestimate Cohen‚Äôs Œ∫\kappa small degree1, overall, differences correlated independent scenarios likely small magnitude, unless higher correlations diagnostic criteria introduced data-generating process.2

what: Assign cognitive impairment status using Bezdicek et al.'s (2017) normative calculator ‚Äî assign_cognitive_impairment
title: Assign cognitive impairment status using Bezdicek et al.'s (2017) normative calculator ‚Äî assign_cognitive_impairment
text: Applies cognitive impairment classification based z-scores computed via normative regression calculator Bezdicek et al. (2017), following Level II PD-MCI criteria proposed Litvan et al. (2012). patient classified cognitively impaired two test scores z < -1.5.

title: Assign cognitive impairment status using Bezdicek et al.'s (2017) normative calculator ‚Äî assign_cognitive_impairment
Assign cognitive impairment status using Bezdicek et al.'s (2017) normative calculator ‚Äî assign_cognitive_impairment
text: d0 list data, typically generated prepare_data, containing test scores. calc character string specifying file path regression calculator (.xlsx format). map data frame, tibble, matrix : Column 1: Label used calculator file Column 2: Corresponding label data Column 3: Cognitive domain test Column 4: Indicator score direction (1 normal, -1 reversed) Alternatively, semicolon-delimited CSV file path containing table. output character string specifying output format: "ci" ‚Äì return logical indicator cognitive impairment "z" ‚Äì return z-scores index "" ‚Äì return (default)

title: Assign cognitive impairment status using Bezdicek et al.'s (2017) normative calculator ‚Äî assign_cognitive_impairment
text: Depending output argument: "ci" logical vector indicating cognitive impairment (TRUE/FALSE). "z" data frame computed z-scores per cognitive test. "" list two elements: z (z-scores) ci (impairment status).

what: Compute z-score(s) based on raw scores and demographic regression model ‚Äî compute_z_score
title: Compute z-score(s) based on raw scores and demographic regression model ‚Äî compute_z_score
text: Computes z-scores given test index using regression parameters normative calculator, along patient's raw score demographic information (age, gender, education).

title: Compute z-score(s) based on raw scores and demographic regression model ‚Äî compute_z_score
code: compute_z_score(calc, x, nam, AGE, GEN, EDU)

title: Compute z-score(s) based on raw scores and demographic regression model ‚Äî compute_z_score
text: calc data frame tibble containing regression parameters calculator. x numeric vector raw performance scores. nam character string specifying test index label (must match entry calc). AGE numeric vector indicating participant's age (years). GEN numeric vector indicating gender (1 = man, 0 = woman). EDU numeric vector indicating years education.

title: Compute z-score(s) based on raw scores and demographic regression model ‚Äî compute_z_score
text: numeric vector computed z-scores, one raw score x.

title: Compute z-score(s) based on raw scores and demographic regression model ‚Äî compute_z_score

what: Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
title: Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
text: comprehensive table containing pairwise comparisons 68 diagnostic algorithms Parkinson‚Äôs Disease Dementia (PDD) evaluated study. table serves basis Figures 2, A3, A4, A5, well summary results presented throughout article.

title: Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
text: tibble 7,744 rows 20 columns: predictor Character; name algorithm used predictor. reference Character; name algorithm used reference. Kappa Character; Cohen‚Äôs kappa 95% confidence interval. Accuracy Character; accuracy estimate 95% confidence interval. Kappa_raw Numeric; Cohen‚Äôs kappa estimate. McnemarPValue Numeric; p-value McNemar‚Äôs chi-squared test symmetry rows columns. Accuracy_raw Numeric; accuracy estimate. NoInformationRate_raw Numeric; -information rate, .e., accuracy patients classified non-PDD. AccuracyPValue Numeric; p-value Exact Binomial Test comparing accuracy -information rate. Sensitivity Numeric; sensitivity estimate. Specificity Numeric; specificity estimate. Pos Pred Value Numeric; positive predictive value. Neg Pred Value Numeric; negative predictive value. Precision Numeric; precision estimate. Recall Numeric; recall estimate. F1 Numeric; F1 score. Prevalence Numeric; PDD prevalence according reference algorithm. Detection Rate Numeric; detection rate. Detection Prevalence Numeric; detection prevalence. Balanced Accuracy Numeric; balanced accuracy, .e., (sensitivity + specificity) / 2.

title: Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
text: Generated targets pipeline _targets.R.

title: Table of Pairwise Concordance Measures ‚Äî concords
text: algorithm used reference predictor, meaning algorithm pair appears twice. metrics, Cohen‚Äôs kappa, symmetrical, whereas others (e.g., accuracy, sensitivity, specificity) .

what: Define file paths to raw data for analysis ‚Äî data_paths
title: Define file paths to raw data for analysis ‚Äî data_paths
text: Prepares set file paths pointing required raw data files used analysis. function enforces naming conventions validates compatibility contents specified directory expected structure. intended used input prepare_data function.

title: Define file paths to raw data for analysis ‚Äî data_paths
Define file paths to raw data for analysis ‚Äî data_paths
text: dir character string specifying input directory raw data files reside. Defaults "data-raw".

title: Define file paths to raw data for analysis ‚Äî data_paths
text: named character vector file paths required raw data files.

title: Define file paths to raw data for analysis ‚Äî data_paths

what: Compute and visualise measures of concordance between diagnostic criteria ‚Äî describe_concordance
title: Compute and visualise measures of concordance between diagnostic criteria ‚Äî describe_concordance
text: Computes pairwise concordance statistics different operationalisations probable Parkinson‚Äôs disease dementia (PDD). Metrics include Cohen's Kappa, Sensitivity, Positive Predictive Value (PPV), Specificity, Negative Predictive Value (NPV), Accuracy. Visual summaries also generated.

title: Compute and visualise measures of concordance between diagnostic criteria ‚Äî describe_concordance
Compute and visualise measures of concordance between diagnostic criteria ‚Äî describe_concordance
text: d0 list containing PDD diagnostic results, produced diagnose_pdd_sample.

title: Compute and visualise measures of concordance between diagnostic criteria ‚Äî describe_concordance
text: list two components: table data frame summarising pairwise concordance statistics (e.g., Kappa, Accuracy, Sensitivity, Specificity, PPV, NPV). plots list ggplot2-based visualisations, including matrices Cohen's Kappa, Accuracy (significance tests Information Rate), Sensitivity, Specificity.

title: Compute and visualise measures of concordance between diagnostic criteria ‚Äî describe_concordance
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p) pdd <- diagnose_pdd_sample(data) concmats <- describe_concordance(pdd) } # }

what: Diagnose PDD in a single patient sample using specified criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_case
title: Diagnose PDD in a single patient sample using specified criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_case
text: Applies specified set diagnostic criteria data matrix representing patient-level data determine whether patient meets criteria probable Parkinson‚Äôs disease dementia (PDD). function intended used internally wrapper function diagnose_pdd_sample.

title: Diagnose PDD in a single patient sample using specified criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_case
Diagnose PDD in a single patient sample using specified criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_case
text: x data frame matrix containing patient-level variables used diagnosis. c named vector (single-row data frame) specifying criteria applied PDD diagnosis.

title: Diagnose PDD in a single patient sample using specified criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_case
text: logical vector indicating PDD diagnosis patient (TRUE = diagnosed, FALSE = diagnosed).

title: Diagnose PDD in a single patient sample using specified criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_case
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p) crit <- specify_criteria() pdd  <- diagnose_pdd_case(data, crit[1, ]) } # }

what: Diagnose PDD in all patients using all available criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_sample
title: Diagnose PDD in all patients using all available criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_sample
text: Applies available diagnostic criteria probable Parkinson‚Äôs disease dementia (PDD) across full dataset. set criteria generated internally via specify_criteria function. patient assessed using specification, corresponding diagnoses supporting information recorded.

title: Diagnose PDD in all patients using all available criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_sample
Diagnose PDD in all patients using all available criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_sample
text: d0 tibble containing dataset prepared using prepare_data.

title: Diagnose PDD in all patients using all available criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_sample
text: list two tibbles: criteria tibble containing full specification criteria used. diagnoses tibble containing: Patient ID Criterion label (linked specification) PDD diagnosis (TRUE/FALSE) Individual diagnostic flags corresponding Table 2 Dubois et al. (2007) Impairment labels across cognitive domains (per Level criteria)

title: Diagnose PDD in all patients using all available criteria ‚Äî diagnose_pdd_sample
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p) pdd  <- diagnose_pdd_sample(data) } # }

what: Summarise data using predefined summary types ‚Äî do_summary
title: Summarise data using predefined summary types ‚Äî do_summary
text: Computes descriptive summaries given vector, optionally including graphical representation (planned future versions). Supports various summary types tailored continuous, binary, nominal variables.

title: Summarise data using predefined summary types ‚Äî do_summary
Summarise data using predefined summary types ‚Äî do_summary
text: x vector data summarised. dec integer specifying number decimal places numeric summaries. sum character string specifying type summary compute. Possible values: NULL (default) Simple printing vector "N" Number observations "msd" Mean +/- standard deviation "M" Mean "SD" Standard deviation "Md" Median "IQR" Interquartile range "minmax" Minimum-maximum range "Min" Minimum "Max" Maximum "p" p-value (formatted tables) "ptext" p-value (formatted -text reporting) "Nperc" Count percentage binary variables "Nslash" Counts separated slashes nominal variables number categories "estCI" Estimate confidence interval, e.g., "estimate [CI]"

title: Summarise data using predefined summary types ‚Äî do_summary
text: character string numeric summary specified sum.

title: Summarise data using predefined summary types ‚Äî do_summary
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p)  M <- do_summary(data[, 25], 2, "M") SD <- do_summary(data[, 25], 2, "SD") Md <- do_summary(data[, 25], 2, "Md") mm <- do_summary(data[, 25], 0, "minmax") } # }

what: Generate an APA-style table using the gt package ‚Äî gt_apa_table
title: Generate an APA-style table using the gt package ‚Äî gt_apa_table
text: Converts tibble data frame APA-formatted table using gt package. resulting object inherits features customizations provided gt.

title: Generate an APA-style table using the gt package ‚Äî gt_apa_table
code: gt_apa_table(x, grp = NULL, nms = NULL, tit = "")

title: Generate an APA-style table using the gt package ‚Äî gt_apa_table
text: x tibble data frame formatted APA-style table. grp optional column name (string symbol) use grouping rows via gt::gt()'s groupname_col parameter. Defaults NULL. nms optional column name (string symbol) use row names via gt::gt()'s rowname_col parameter. Defaults NULL. tit character string specifying table title. converted HTML format. Defaults "Name".

title: Generate an APA-style table using the gt package ‚Äî gt_apa_table
text: gt table object formatted according APA style.

title: Import item-data ‚Äî import_item_data
text: Imports item-level data specified file path, checks unrealistic values (e.g., MMSE scores), prepares data processing. function intended called within larger prepare_data workflow.

title: Import item-data ‚Äî import_item_data
Import item-data ‚Äî import_item_data
text: path character string specifying path data file. Typically generated data_paths function.

title: Import item-data ‚Äî import_item_data
text: tibble containing item-level data.

title: Import item-data ‚Äî import_item_data
Import REDCap data ‚Äî import_redcap_data
text: Imports REDCap dataset specified file path using scoring information. function prepares data suitable format intended used within broader prepare_data workflow.

title: Import REDCap data ‚Äî import_redcap_data
Import REDCap data ‚Äî import_redcap_data
text: path character string specifying path REDCap data file. Typically generated data_paths function. scoring tibble containing scoring conventions variables interest.

title: Import REDCap data ‚Äî import_redcap_data
text: tibble containing imported processed REDCap data.

title: Import REDCap data ‚Äî import_redcap_data
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") scor <- readr::read_delim(p[4], delim = ";", col_types = readr::cols(rev = "c")) data <- import_redcap_data(p[2]) } # }

what: Prepare a list of algorithms stratified by IADL mesure ‚Äî list_algos
title: Prepare a list of algorithms stratified by IADL mesure ‚Äî list_algos
text: Using table PDD rates estimates per diagnostic algorithm, function extracts list algorithms using different IADL criteria PDD. algorithm uses criteria time, function prints error.

title: Prepare a list of algorithms stratified by IADL mesure ‚Äî list_algos
Prepare a list of algorithms stratified by IADL mesure ‚Äî list_algos
text: rates tibble containing raw summaries PDD rates generated summarise_rates.

title: Prepare a list of algorithms stratified by IADL mesure ‚Äî list_algos
text: list two components: faq_tot character vector containing names algorithms defined IADL deficit FAQ total score > 7. faq_9 character vector containing names algorithms defined IADL deficit FAQ item 9 > 1.

title: Prepare a list of algorithms stratified by IADL mesure ‚Äî list_algos
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p) pdd  <- diagnose_pdd_sample(data) vars <- here::here("data-raw", "VariablesOfInterest.csv")  rates <- summarise_rates(pdd, vars) algos <- list_algos(rates$table) } # }

what: Make a Dendrogram of PDD Algorithms ‚Äî make_dendrogram
title: Make a Dendrogram of PDD Algorithms ‚Äî make_dendrogram
text: functions prepares dendrogram (tree plot) summarises PDD algorithms construction starting IADL operationalisation top follow successively opreationalisation Global cognitive performance, Attention, Executive Function, Construction, Memory Language. dendrogram visualises PDD rate estimated algorithm via point size associated .

title: Make a Dendrogram of PDD Algorithms ‚Äî make_dendrogram
Make a Dendrogram of PDD Algorithms ‚Äî make_dendrogram
text: tab table containing criteria used generated summarise_rates.

title: Make a Dendrogram of PDD Algorithms ‚Äî make_dendrogram
text: ggplot object dendrogram created ggraph.

title: Pre-process data for analysis ‚Äî prepare_data
text: Takes file paths raw data, checks format compatibility, valid, proceeds import pre-process data analysis. function serves main entry point assembling clean dataset raw sources.

title: Pre-process data for analysis ‚Äî prepare_data
Pre-process data for analysis ‚Äî prepare_data
text: p named character vector file paths generated data_paths. check.names logical indicating whether check_names run compare names meta data item data.

title: Pre-process data for analysis ‚Äî prepare_data
text: tibble containing cleaned pre-processed variables ready analysis. function also performs validation checks prints warnings stops execution critical issues detected (e.g., mismatched names, --range values).

title: Pre-process data for analysis ‚Äî prepare_data

what: Regress probable PDD on age and sex across diagnostic criteria ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
title: Regress probable PDD on age and sex across diagnostic criteria ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
text: operationalisation probable Parkinson‚Äôs disease dementia (PDD), function fits logistic regression model predicting diagnosis age, sex, interaction. takes input demographic data tibble PDD diagnoses (typically generated via diagnose_pdd_sample).

title: Regress probable PDD on age and sex across diagnostic criteria ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
Regress probable PDD on age and sex across diagnostic criteria ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
text: d0 tibble demographic data generated prepare_data. d1 tibble PDD diagnoses (typically PDD element list returned diagnose_pdd_sample). form character containing linear model formula. Defaults "PDD ~ age * sex" altered include covariates.

title: Regress probable PDD on age and sex across diagnostic criteria ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
text: list following components: fits list fitted logistic regression models PDD criterion. values tibble model coefficients statistics. plots named list ggplot2 objects: data Plots showing raw proportions PDD diagnoses age sex. parameters Plots summarising effect sizes (odds ratios) associated p-values.

title: Regress probable PDD on age and sex across diagnostic criteria ‚Äî regress_pdd_on_demographics
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data0 <- prepare_data(p) data1 <- diagnose_pdd_sample(data0) results <- regress_pdd_on_demographics(data0, data1$PDD) } # }

what: Specify criteria operationalisations for PDD diagnosis ‚Äî specify_criteria
title: Specify criteria operationalisations for PDD diagnosis ‚Äî specify_criteria
text: Computes Cartesian product possible diagnostic components define combinations operationalised criteria probable Parkinson‚Äôs disease dementia (PDD). function helper typically called within diagnose_pdd_sample.

title: Specify criteria operationalisations for PDD diagnosis ‚Äî specify_criteria
Specify criteria operationalisations for PDD diagnosis ‚Äî specify_criteria
text: tibble row represents one unique operationalisation PDD diagnostic criteria. Columns indicate type criteria, individual test indexes, thresholds, relevant parameters.

what: Prepare a list of algorithms stratified by IADL mesure ‚Äî summarise_kappa
title: Prepare a list of algorithms stratified by IADL mesure ‚Äî summarise_kappa
text: Using table PDD rates estimates per diagnostic algorithm, function extracts list algorithms using different IADL criteria PDD. algorithm uses criteria time, function prints error.

title: Prepare a list of algorithms stratified by IADL mesure ‚Äî summarise_kappa
Prepare a list of algorithms stratified by IADL mesure ‚Äî summarise_kappa
text: algorithms tibble containing raw summaries PDD rates generated summarise_rates. concordance description

title: Prepare a list of algorithms stratified by IADL mesure ‚Äî summarise_kappa
text: list two components: faq_tot numeric vector containing Cohen's kappas algorithm pairs IADL deficit defined FAQ total > 7. faq_9 numeric vector containing Cohen's kappas algorithm pairs IADL deficit defined FAQ item 9 > 1. cross numeric vector containing Cohen's kappas algorithm pairs different IADL deficit definitions. iadl numeric vector containing Cohen's kappas algorithm pairs differ IADL deficit definition. sums named character vector containing mean standard deviation vector Kappas contained list.

what: Orders and prints algorithms based on their estimated PDD rates ‚Äî summarise_rates
title: Orders and prints algorithms based on their estimated PDD rates ‚Äî summarise_rates
text: function computes summaries estimated PDD rates, stratified diagnostic operationalisation.

title: Orders and prints algorithms based on their estimated PDD rates ‚Äî summarise_rates
Orders and prints algorithms based on their estimated PDD rates ‚Äî summarise_rates
text: d0 list PDD data generated via diagnose_pdd_sample. vars data.frame, tibble, matrix variable names first column, variable labels second column, type variable (continuous, binary, nominal) third column, optionally fourth column denoting group fifth column mapping label description table‚Äôs note. Alternatively, path CSV file (semicolon-delimited) containing table. descending logical indicating whether operationalisations highest estimated PDD rates listed first (default TRUE).

title: Orders and prints algorithms based on their estimated PDD rates ‚Äî summarise_rates
text: list : table tibble containing raw summaries PDD rates. plot ggplot2 object visualising estimated PDD rates. gtable named list gt tables: gtab_rates APA-style gt table summarising results. gtab_algos APA-style gt table listing algorithms used.

title: Orders and prints algorithms based on their estimated PDD rates ‚Äî summarise_rates
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ p <- data_paths("data-raw") data <- prepare_data(p) pdd  <- diagnose_pdd_sample(data) vars <- here::here("data-raw", "VariablesOfInterest.csv")  rates0 <- summarise_rates(pdd, vars) rates1 <- summarise_rates(pdd, vars, TRUE)  # rates0 and rates1 are identical rates2 <- summarise_rates(pdd, vars, FALSE) # ascending order } # }

title: Generate a summary table of PDD criteria used in the study ‚Äî table_criteria
text: function creates pre-specified summary table probable PDD criteria compared study. intended shortcut insert clean table Quarto document without cluttering main text. table content hardcoded can changed modifying function code.

title: Generate a summary table of PDD criteria used in the study ‚Äî table_criteria
Generate a summary table of PDD criteria used in the study ‚Äî table_criteria
text: vars data.frame, tibble, matrix variable names first column, variable labels second column, variable type (continuous, binary, nominal) third column, optional fourth column indicating group, fifth column mapping label note description. Alternatively, path semicolon-delimited CSV file containing table.

title: Generate a summary table of PDD criteria used in the study ‚Äî table_criteria
text: gt table object containing summary criteria used study.

what: Generate a summary table of study estimands ‚Äî table_estimands
title: Generate a summary table of study estimands ‚Äî table_estimands
text: function creates pre-specified table provides verbal summary study's estimands inclusion Appendix. intended shortcut insert clean, structured description Quarto document without cluttering main text. table content fixed can modified editing function's code directly.

title: Generate a summary table of study estimands ‚Äî table_estimands
Generate a summary table of study estimands ‚Äî table_estimands
text: gt table object summarising theoretical estimands, empirical estimands, corresponding statistical estimates used study.

what: Generate summary table of top and bottom Level I algorithms in predicting Level II-derived probable PDD ‚Äî table_levelII_approximations
title: Generate summary table of top and bottom Level I algorithms in predicting Level II-derived probable PDD ‚Äî table_levelII_approximations
text: helper function prepares table showing five best five worst-performing Level algorithms predicting selected Level II-based diagnosis probable PDD. primarily intended use manuscript keep Quarto documents uncluttered.

title: Generate summary table of top and bottom Level I algorithms in predicting Level II-derived probable PDD ‚Äî table_levelII_approximations
Generate summary table of top and bottom Level I algorithms in predicting Level II-derived probable PDD ‚Äî table_levelII_approximations
text: values tibble concordance statistics generated describe_concordance. struct list two elements: [[1]] Character vector Level algorithm names derived using FAQ total > 7 IADL criterion. [[2]] Character vector Level algorithm names derived using FAQ item 9 > 1 IADL criterion. Note: order matters. crit character string indicating Level II algorithm used reference comparison.

title: Generate summary table of top and bottom Level I algorithms in predicting Level II-derived probable PDD ‚Äî table_levelII_approximations
text: gt table object summarising concordance statistics (e.g., accuracy, kappa) five best five worst Level algorithms predicting specified Level II-based diagnosis probable PDD.
